qas.question: What percent of ownership did the merger award the Dutch branch?
What prevented a full-scale merger of the two companies?
What was the primary function of the Anglo-Saxon Petroleum Company?

answers.text: to direct the transport and storage of the products

qas.question: The new firm operated as what type of company?
What percent of ownership of the new company was awarded to the British?
What encouraged a full-scale merger of the two companies?
What british company was in charge at The Hague?
What city were both branches of the new firm located in?
What was the name of the Dutch company in charge of transportation and storage?

plausible_answers.text: National patriotic sensibilities would not permit a full-scale merger

qas.question: Why did the two companies function as a dual-unit partnership for business purposes?

context: For various reasons, the new firm operated as <a3_0>a dual-listed company<a3_0/>, whereby the merging companies maintained their legal existence, but operated as a single-unit partnership for business purposes. The terms of the merger gave <a0_0>60<a0_0/> percent ownership of the new group to the Dutch arm and <a4_0>40<a4_0/> percent to the British. <a1_0><b5_0><b9_0>National patriotic sensibilities<b5_0/><a1_0/> would not permit a full-scale merger<b9_0/> or takeover of either of the two companies. The Dutch company, <b8_0>Koninklijke Nederlandsche Petroleum Maatschappij<b8_0/>, was in charge at The Hague of production and manufacture. A British company was formed, called the <b6_0>Anglo-Saxon Petroleum Company<b6_0/>, based in <b7_0>London<b7_0/>, <a2_0>to direct the transport and storage of the products<a2_0/>.
